title: TROLL PLAYERS. Should a team, with a unanimous vote, prevent a teammate of winning League Points?
body:
How many times did we play a game with a troll among our teammates? That guy, that is grieving, flaming, intentional feeding? And despite that, the other 4 players manage to carry the game! In the end, all 5 players, including the troll, get the League Points.

I really don't think that is fair! Do you? RIOT. What about discouraging that behaviour?

What about including another option in the "Honour Page"? You could include a "Prevent this player from earning League Points" option. If all teammates vote for that, the troll player would end with ZERO League Points for that win and a notification. If it was a promo match for the troll player, it should count as a defeat.
Of course, blocking the troll League Points should be done before honouring another teammate and should not prevent honour someone.

How many times we see things like this one:
"if you don't give me the red/blue buff I will troll/AFK/feed" or "if you don't do this/that I will troll/AFK/feed" 
And the player really does that!! Even if the teammates politely ask to not to do that?

Just for disagreeing on others' strategy, and it does not matter if we are winning, his/her "will/call was not fulfilled/followed" so we "you deserve to lose". 

If you report this player, I might and hope I am wrong, but my feeling is that NOTHING happens. No, I don't think one should get a few days ban for ONE offence like that. I think it would be **MORE REASONABLE AND EDUCATIVE** to lose that match League Points or, if the team loses, perhaps they should lose 2x the value they would normally lose. (Remember that 4 players lost around 20 League Points for that behaviour)


NOTE: 
ONLY RANKED GAMES HAVE LEAGUE POINTS.

Ohh, you'd be wrong on that. I strictly play Ranked only unless for some reason I have to do otherwise, and it's shamefully simple to get the other 3 players on your team to bully a single player. Shit, people get flamed for literally ONE death. You don't think that it's an easy matter to get your team to agree that someone doing noticeably bad is "trolling"?

The system would just mean that the guy who seemed to be the weakest would be spanked by the others even if the team won. The only way to protect yourself from that would be to play Duo. Solos would be at the receiving end of this new stick. And since that would be so, some of these seemingly weakest would work to ensure that the rest of the team won't get LPs either. I don't see any positive value in the suggested system, only drawbacks.   - and if I may I point out; I am neutral in the matter, since I don't play ranked.

> If you don't agree with that, I would say there is a big chance you are a toxic player.

What a perfect illustration of why your idea is so flawed. All it took for you to label somebody as toxic is that person disagreeing with you.
There are more than enough people who confuse disagreement on strategy (or even just bad stats) with trolling.

The largest problem, though, is that this will affect people unevenly. If everybody had the same chance to become a false positive under this system it would still feel shitty, but at least it would be balanced out.
But that's not the case:
- Players who go for less popular strategies (no matter how viable) are more likely to run into people who disagree with them.
- Supports that lack any flashy abilities will find it less easy to defend themselves against people claiming they are useless.
- High risk, high reward champions run a high risk to get less LP because of "feeding", while their high reward still only nets them regular LP.
I hope those are enough to convey my point. If not, I'm sure I can come up with more.

And just so we are clear here: I'm not even talking about people abusing the system. I'm talking about situations where people might actually feel *justified* in their use of the system. The chance that people may intentionally screw over people they believe to be innocent is a whole problem of its own.
I think there is a difference between "you are" or "a big chance you are". But anyway, my apologies.

That doesn't change the fact that your judgement (even if it only was a judgement on the likelihood) was just based on the fact that you couldn't see another reason somebody might oppose your idea; or at least not a likely reason.

And that translates perfectly into in-game experiences I've had. People who can't see why somebody might be doing badly through no fault of their own, or why somebody might have made a certain decision (especially if that decision backfired), or why somebody might pick a certain championâ€¦ or even just why somebody might just legitimately be bad at one part of the game.

And when you give people who are unable/unwilling to actually understand another person's motivation the direct power to judge other players at the push of a button bad things are bound to happen.

One other thing I until now struggled to put in words:
The safety guard for requiring four votes doesn't work as well against those cases, either. That's because even if we consider the votes to be independent in a colloquial sense, they are definitely not independent in a statistical sense.
People don't just randomly decide that somebody is a troll. There is always something (even if that something is a misconception, misunderstanding or otherwise inconclusive) that sparks somebody's suspicion. And even if we ignore how common scapegoats and bandwagons are, the chance that all four players come to the same (possibly wrong) conclusion because of that thing that happened is still going to be fairly high.

Edit: Going to add in some made up numbers to help convey my point more rigorously. Just might take a bit.

Edit2: Here we go. Let's say the chance of a randomly picked player **falsely** suspecting another player to be trolling is about 5%.
Now if this was a completely random mistake, your safeguard would lower the chance of somebody being punished false positively to an incredibly low number. After all you need to have this happen four times "in a row".
So the chance for a proper false positive punishment would be 0.05 \* 0.05 \* 0.05 \* 0.05 = 0.000625%
That's one in 160.000

But the suspicion is not a random mistake. This 5% chance is comprised of very specific events that cause the suspicion.
Let's say, for the sake of the argument that 90% of the time somebody picks Teemo, that person is falsely suspected of trolling by a random player. Teemo has a pick rate of 2%, meaning about one third of the cases of false suspicion by one player are Teemo picks.

Here's where it gets interesting: 
You have a 2% chance of Teemo being picked, and then a 90% chance to the power of four that all other four players suspect that pllayer of trolling. That yields 0.02 \* 0.9 \* 0.9 \* 0.9 \* 0.9 = 1.3%
That's one in 76. Our false positive rate has just sky-rocketedâ€¦ and so far we only took a closer look at about one third of the cases.

Worse still: If **you** decide to pick Teemo, the chance that somebody picks Teemo isâ€¦ wellâ€¦ 100%. And Teemo's pick rate is an incredibly important factor. The chance that any Teemo is suspected of trolling by all four other players is 0.9 \* 0.9 \* 0.9 \* 0.9 = **65.6%**.

Obviously the numbers I used here are completely made upâ€¦ but I'm not trying to estimate the actual chance of false positives; I don't even think I would be able to. I just want to highlight why requiring four votes is not necessarily as strong a safeguard as it may sound intuitively. Mostly because our intuition is typically based on simplified and generalized statistical averages.
This is just a way for four players to gang up on a teammate. There is already a system in place - the IFS - to punish players who engage in forbidden behaviors like flaming or inting.

Does this system remove League Points from that player? No? So I think it is not enough. Does the player get banned for 5 minutes? 20 minutes? 1 week? Fine for them, just get another account and play. Then goes back with all your League Points and elo. If the permanent bans were applied more often, we would not have a community as toxic as we have. We should not permanently ban a player for trolling ONE game, but surely we should not reward him with League Points for that game. If we do not punish hard enough bad behaviours, it will not change.
